sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using block matrices:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}$

Find the values of $x_1, x_2, y_1,$ and $y_2$.
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations, we first need to find the inverse of the given matrices and then multiply both sides of the equation by the inverse matrix.

Let's start with the first equation:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

First, find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$:

The determinant is $1 \cdot 4 - (-2) \cdot 3 = 4 + 6 = 10$. The inverse of the matrix is:

$\frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, multiply both sides of the equation by the inverse matrix:

$\frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ -2 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \right) = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

Simplify:

$\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} + \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

Multiply the matrices:

$\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} + \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 11 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 14 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}$

Subtract the matrix:

$\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 14 - 11 \\ 9 - 3 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 6 \end{bmatrix}$

So, $x_1 = \frac{3}{10}$ and $x_2 = \frac{6}{10} = \frac{3}{5}$.

Now, let's solve the second equation:

$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}$

First, find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$:

The determinant is $5 \cdot 2 - (-2) \cdot 1 = 10 + 2 = 12$. The inverse of the matrix is:

$\frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, multiply both sides of the equation by the inverse matrix:

$\frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 5 & -2 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} \right) = \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}$

Simplify:

$\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} + \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 9 \end{bmatrix}$

Multiply the matrices:

$\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} + \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 14 \\ 17 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 43 \end{bmatrix}$

Subtract the matrix:

$\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 20 - 14 \\ 43 - 17 \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{12} \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 26 \end{bmatrix}$

So, $y_1 = \frac{1}{2}$ and $y_2 = \frac{13}{6}$.

Thus, the values of the variables are $x_1 = \frac{3}{10}, x_2 = \frac{3}{5}, y_1 = \frac{1}{2},$ and $y_2 = \frac{13}{6}$.
